name: Cold shoulder one
description:
Video art stills as NFT One of three from "Cold shoulder"
“Cold shoulder” Alison Williams
Video art still (performance based works)

The melting point of ice at 1 atmosphere of pressure is very close to 0 °C (32 °F, 273.15 K), this is also known as the ice point. In “Cold Shoulder”, the artist investigates the term literally. Defined as "A display of coldness or indifference, intended to wound."
Historically the origin of this expression which is often repeated is that visitors to a house who were welcome were given a hot meal but those who weren't were offered only ' cold shoulder of mutton'. This is repeated in several etymological texts, including Hendrickson's usually reliable 'Encyclopedia of Word and Phrase Origins'. There's no evidence to support this view though and it appears to be an example of folk etymology. The first reference to the phrase in print is in Sir Walter Scott's 'The Antiquary', 1816: "The Countess’s dislike didna gang farther at first than just showing o’ the cauld shouther". 'Cauld' is Scottish dialect for 'cold'. alison williams 2010 video 16:9 stills
